Award.AbstractNarration:
The 8th Meeting on Hydrodynamic Quantum Analogs (HQA8) is scheduled to be
held on July 23-27, 2018 at Brown University. We anticipate that the meeting will be attended
by approximately 30 participants from countries worldwide including: United States, Mexico,
Brazil, Belgium, Australia, and the United Kingdom. HQA8 it the eighth of a series of meetings
on a field that began with the pioneering work of Yves Couder and Emmanuel Fort on walking
droplets. A liquid droplet can ?walk? by bouncing on the surface of a vibrating bath of the same
liquid through a resonant interaction with the wave field it creates. The ensemble of drop and
waves has been called a walker, which constitutes a wave-particle association at the macroscopic
scale which have been shown to exhibit several quantum-like features. Funding will be used to
provide travel support for students and researchers that would otherwise be unable to attend as
well as to support some costs associated with the workshop itself.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 8th Meeting on Hydrodynamic Quantum Analogs (HQA8) was held on July 23-27, 2018 at Brown University. The meeting was attended by approximately 30 participants from countries worldwide including the US, Mexico, France, Brazil, Australia, UK, and Belgium.The meeting boosted collaborations between groups working on hydrodynamic quantum analogs, while extending the collaborations to quantum physicists who are interested in the rich behavior of walkers. The scientific contents from the meeting are stored on a Brown-domain website and are available to the public. HQA8 was the eighth of a series of meetings on a field that began with the pioneering work of Yves Couder and Emmanuel Fort on walking droplets or "walkers". Walkers have sparked the interest of scientists for being a macroscopic system exhibiting some behaviors thought to be exclusive to the microscopic, quantum world. The workshop provided participants with an opportunity to share their findings and take part in discussions with the growing HQA community. Funding allowed students and researchers from abroad who could not afford the cost of travel and accommodation to join the meeting. The funding also allowed for an inexpensive setup that allows for the striking visualization of the basic phenomenology of walkers to be implemented for the event and used for a Student Visualization Workshop for student attendees, led by the PI.


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Daniel M Harris

HQA8 was the eighth of a series of meetings on a field that began with the pioneering work of Yves Couder and Emmanuel Fort on walking droplets or "walkers". Walkers have sparked the interest of scientists for being a macroscopic system exhibiting some behaviors thought to be exclusive to the microscopic, quantum world.
